title: Chinese explosion hits sales at Jaguar Land Rover
text:

Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 23:09 BST - UK Markets closed Chinese explosion hits sales at Jaguar Land Rover By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 41 minutes ago Print 
The carmaker is recovering from the August blast in Tianjin, which damaged 5,800 vehicles 
Jaguar Land Rover has been hit by an exceptional charge after thousands of its cars were ruined by the huge blast at the Chinese port city of Tianjin . 
Reporting quarterly figures, the Coventry-based premium car make r said that its performance stalled after 5,800 cars stored in Tianjin were damaged or destroyed by the chemical blast in August. 
“Given the exceptional nature of this event, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is still assessing the damages and it may be some time before the company knows what insurance and other recoveries will be,” the company said in a statement. 
“In these circumstances, there is likely to be a one-time exceptional charge in the second quarter of 2016 before any potential recoveries in subsequent quarters.” 
The company - which is owned by Indian conglomerate Tata - said that global sales slipped by 1pc in three months to the end of September compared with the same period a year ago, with 110,200 cars sold. 
The explosion at Tianjin and China’s slowing economic growth meant that this key market was the biggest faller, with sales down 32pc. 
Until recently China has been responsible for about a fifth of all of the company’s sales and, according to industry experts, about 80pc of profits as JLR has been able to charge a premium for its vehicles there. 
However, Chinese car sales are seen to be moving in line with other markets as the slowdown in the country’s economy and the Beijing government looking at the prices auto companies charge hit sales. 
JLR’s overseas market, which includes Russia, Brazil and the Middle East and North Africa, were 12pc lower in the period, but the company said strong growth elsewhere help prop up its performance. 
Europe was up 34pc, North America gained 23pc and the UK was 9pc higher. 
Sales strengthened in the end of the quarter , rising 3pc on the same month a year ago to 47,634 vehicles, beating the record number turned in in September 2014. 
In first nine months of 2015, total sales were 349,412 vehicles, in line with the prior year. 
The introduction of Jaguar’s “baby” XE helped the marque lift sales in September by 22pc to 10,394, while Land Rover’s sales for the month dropped 1pc to 37,240.
